captions.text:
Sand, whether you use it for building sand
castles, telling time with an hourglass, or

hydraulic fracturing, is pretty much the same
just about anywhere you go -- an uncountable

number of tiny grains mixed together to form
the same dunes and beaches.

But why does sand almost always look the same?
And how does so much of it end up at the beach?

Well, much of the world's sand is made out
of the same stuff-- tiny crystals of the mineral

quartz, which is made out of silicon and oxygen,
the two most common elements in Earth's crust.

And as you'll know if you've ever bitten through
the crust -- of a sandwich -- that had sand

in it -- quartz grains are small, and really
tough. Here's why:

Quartz crystals form within a cooling blob
of molten granite rock, or magma, deep under

Earth's surface. As the magma cools, different
minerals crystallize into solid rock at different

temperatures, and quartz is one of the last
minerals to form. It's forced to crystallize

in the tiny spaces left in the now cooling
rock, pretty much ensuring that it ends up
in a specific size range.

But being last has lasting advantages. Minerals
that do form in the earlier, hotter conditions

have weaker chemical structures and weather
away more easily than quartz, kind of like

how a relationship forged in the heat of passion
might not be as stable as a deep bond developed

over time. So as the weak, flash-in-the-pan
minerals wear away, the unfaltering quartz

grains are left to pop out of the rock as
sand!

And then it's only a matter of time--sometimes
a very long time-- before the quartz sand

gets whisked away by streams and rivers and
carried to the sea. There, at the mouth of

a river, the fast-flowing water slows abruptly,
and the well-rounded sand drops out. Larger

rocks and pebbles were already left behind
upstream, while smaller sediments like silt

and clay continue to be swept along by the
weakened current and are deposited further
from shore.

Over thousands and thousands of years, the
paths of rivers sweep up and down the coast,

dropping off piles of sand to be spread by
waves and currents into smooth sandy beaches.

Of course, not all beaches are purely quartz
sand, and not all quartz sand ends up on beaches

- but the fact that so many beaches and so
many sands are the same is a testament to

the chemistry of the most common components
of earth's crust as they cool and crystallize,

and to the physics of sediments slowly shifting
and surging towards the sea. They are, quite
literally, the real sands of time.

title: Why is All Sand the Same?

comments.text:
Though mostly correct and yes the formation you describe does occur. Quartz 
would not usually crystallize in the same location as amphibolite and 
olivine. As those weaker "mafic", meaning silica poor, silicate minerals 
like olivine cool and solidify at the higher temperatures they tend to 
settle to the bottom of the magma chamber. leaving, more felsic minerals 
like feldspar, mica, and quartz to form the top of the cooling magma 
chamber. The reason most beaches are made of this quartz not olivine is 
because of how small olivine particles tend to be because of their weak 
structural bonds their size makes them more likely to be washed out to sea, 
while the larger stronger quartz particles settle out.﻿

comments.text:

'Self,' like 'Society,' isn't a thing; it's the detritus of things that

comments.author: woobmonkey

comments.author: bob balls

comments.text:
When we say something is in front of us we mean there is some distance 
between that thing and the outermost part of our body(the part of our body 
that is the closest to the thing). When we say something is below us we 
mean there is a vertical distance between that thing and the lowest part of 
our body(our feet if we're standing straight). If you cut a person in half 
it's still a person and the half that doesn't include his brain(say his 
lower abdomen and legs) is just a part of that person's body. The 'piece' 
that's considered a person is the central nervous system. That's everything 
you'll see, hear, remember, every thought you'll ever make, every emotion 
you'll feel and everything else that makes you an individual person is 
because of it.

comments.author: Joe Parks

comments.text:
The author of this is obviously not a geologist. A sedimentologist can 
identify which outcrop sand comes from with a petrographic microscope. Sand 
is a size--one may as well ask "why are all inches the same?" What is being 
discussed here is mature sand: very round, overwhelmingly quartz sand. 
Immature/young sands have a higher proportion of unstable minerals, and 
angular grains, due to their closer proximity to the source material. I've 
worked with some formations where the source was so close to the 
depositional setting that there was, essentially, no change in the 
material, even the least stable grains (micas and feldspars in this 
case)--in fact, the only way to tell the difference between "source" and 
"sediment" was how hard the stuff was!﻿

+Zizi Mugen Ah. It's the former, at least for you.

Given the choice between so-called "pop science" videos which are 
inaccurate but nevertheless interesting and no science videos at all, I 
believe the former is preferable. That's just my opinion though.

Just to be clear, I'm not at all disagreeing with you. You probably do know 
your stuff and you probably know exactly how wrong this video is. This 
response is by no means an attack on how much you know about geology.

That being said, I'm sure you can email the channel producers directly 
about their mistakes and they would probably be glad to hear about it. 
Constructive criticism is always useful. Calling this video an abomination 
to geology and acting like this video *genuinely ruined your day* is, at 
the very least, unhealthy. Once you send your concerns, there's no reason 
to let the video keep bothering you.

comments.author: T3n50r

comments.text:
I found this video poorly made.  Your explanation of quartz size/shape 
uniformity and resistance to weathering as solely due to crystallization 
order (i.e. Bowen's reaction series) has some basis, but you must address 
the evolution of detritus during transport.  That's the basis of the 
sediment maturity and the meaning of words like detritus and clastic!  Your 
reference to sand being other places and not touching on paleoenviroments, 
such as beaches, of exhumed sediments was an oversight.  Your failure to 
define what sand is made this video a tool to reinforce preconceived 
notions.  And you didn't even spell orthoclase correctly.  I could go on 
with these problems but I shouldn't be able to for a two and a half minute 
video!﻿
comments.author: Benjamin Dover

comments.text:

 No, I'm saying a two and a half minute video on a fairly large topic can 
only be concise and effective if the creator understands far more than the 
video conveys, in order to select the relevant information.  In this case, 
I think the prioritization of ideas was made with poor judgement because he 
doesn't understand the issue very well.  Cute graphics though.  I didn't 
publish these comments for the supposed education of > 2 million people, so 
forgive my grammar.  I think there is a difference between a slight 
grammatical error and misspelling one of 7 words (beyond the frames where 
he takes credit) in the entire video, and a name at that.  He corrected 
himself in the description, anyways.

P.S. I wouldn't watch or comment on these videos if I didn't appreciate 
many of his other creations.

+Easily Offended Don't Read This... We did not evolve directly from apes. 
Rather we both share common ancestor thay we both evolved from in a 
different way, meaning we evolved with them. Also, if God is real, and he 
creates all living things, why are there genetic diseases? Why are there 
animals born with things such as flightless wings? How is god able to 
manage everything? Your response to that last one is probably something 
along the lines of "It's because he's omnipotent." If god truly is 
omnipotent why are there innocent children dying in accidents that god with 
his magical powers could've easily prevented? What about all the other 
religions of the world? Are they just wrong? You can't prove any of that. 
The whole reason why Christianity and most other religion was created was 
to filll in the gaps and give people closure about things they don't 
understand as the unknown is truly terrifying. If you are a troll (which is 
likely considering your channel name) than have fun with your bait. If you 
had not posted on this video about your beliefs and just kept to yourself, 
I would have been completely fine with you and your beliefs. I'm completely 
fine with religion as long as it's healthy, and leads you down a good path. 
What I'm not okay with, is you going on a video fishing for attention and 
responding to credible arguments with some early millennium ideological 
bullshit.

comments.text:
Great video as always. But one thing to notice is that beach and desert 
sand are NOT the same. Beach sand is more angular and desert sand will be 
rounded.﻿
comments.author: Cam11548

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure its the other way around. Wind (in the desert) produces 
much more angular grains than water (wave action, currents, etc.) does. 
Waves can do both mechanical and chemical weathering to a parent rock, 
whereas sand in the desert primarily is eroded and transported by wind.  
Water rounds particles overtime, wind produces more angular (squared) 
grains of sand.

Any beach sand that has been weathered so much and for so long becomes so 
fine as to be carried out to sea.

comments.author: David Goldberg

comments.text:
It seems to me that there might be a lot less sand deposited along 
California's beaches because the flow of water from rivers is gigantically 
less than it once was due to water usage. I mean from what I understand the 
water flowing from California streams and rivers used to support Steelhead 
and even Salmon as far south as San Diego where as now these species aren't 
found much farther south than Big Sur and in drastically reduced 
populations. Many communities are experiencing beach erosion. We have 
destroyed the process that deposits sand. I am no expert but that is my 
hypothesis.   ﻿

comments.author: unknownone61

comments.text:
Sounds great and why bother to quantify something that just has to be true, 
or is it?

This isn't quantified either, but I'd like to suggest that weathering from 
granite et al. doesn't begin to explain the quantity and uniformity of 
sand, sandstone and quartzite worldwide, as well as the sand in schist, as 
in Wissahickon schist from my backyard.

Alternatively, if authigenic clay precipitates on high-gravity earth, 
larger authigenic mineral grains would precipitate in the microgravity of 
internal oceans of icy bodies of the extended scattered disc and Oort 
cloud, where 'aqueous differentiation' is initiated by planetesimal 
collisions or spiral in mergers of binary icy bodies.

In
Ragnarok: The Age of Fire and Gravel
Ignatius Loyola Donnelly (November 3, 1831 – January 1, 1901)
describes *The Drift,* which in part has come to be recognized in the form 
of the 'black mat' from the hypothesized End Pleistocene (c. 12,800 years 
ago) air burst impact  on the Laurentide ice sheet that may have formed the 
450 km Nastapoka arc (impact basin) of the lower Hudson bay.

Ragnarok: The Age of Fire and Gravel
The Drift
CHAPTER I.
THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE DRIFT
http://www.sacred-texts.com/atl/rag/rag03.htm﻿

comments.author: young ESQUIRE

comments.text:
The age of a sand and its parent rock determines what it looks like. The 
younger a sand is, the more likely it is to have non-silica grains, and the 
larger, more angular its particles are. Most old sands are almost 
inevitably comprised of fine well rounded silica grains. However there are 
exceptions, such as the basalt sand beaches of Hawaii. There's little to no 
quartz out there.﻿
comments.author: William Reely

comments.text:
Also, many riverbank and lake beach sands are very rich in clay, because 
clay mineral particles are tiny and will go into suspension with little to 
no perturbation to get carried to the edge of the water. Around lakes that 
freeze during the winter, there are occasionally sands made almost entirely 
of clay because clay particles will drop out of suspension and settle out 
when lakes freeze over.
comments.author: William Reely
